# Question

Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

```julia
function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump::Int = 3)
    # Check if dt is a Date type and throw an error if so
    if isa(dt, Date)
        throw(ArgumentError("timezone_bumper can only be applied to DateTime types, not Date types."))
    end

    # Calculate the new DateTime by adding bump hours to the time part of dt
    new_dt = DateTime(year=year(dt), month=month(dt), day=day(dt),
                       hour=hour(dt) + bump, minute=minute(dt), second=second(dt))

    # Return the new DateTime
    return new_dt
end
```

This function checks if the provided `dt` is a `Date` type and throws an error if so. If `dt` is a valid `DateTime`, it adds the specified number of hours to the time part of the date without changing the year, month, or day. The default value for `bump` is set to 3 hours.
